li.p: What is the mathematical notion of limit and what role do limits play in the study of functions?
How do we go about determining the value of the limit of a function at a point?
What is a left-hand limit at x = a and a right-hand limit at x = a?
How do we understand limits for asymptotes and limits to infinity?

introduction.p: What if we only have the function and not the graph? If x=a is in the domain of f(x) then first simply try plugging in a, this will work as long as f(x) is continuous at x=a (see Section 1.4 for more details). We will consider examples of functions for when x=a is not in the domain.

statement.p:
Consider the functions
f(x) =\displaystyle \frac{4-x^2}{x+2};
g(x) =\displaystyle \frac{x^2-9}{x-3};
For both f(x) and g(x) consider the limits for values in and out of the domain. Note first that the domain of f(x) is x\neq-2 and the domain of g(x) is x\neq 3. Thus we can evaluate limits by just plugging in values for any other point.
\lim_{x \to 0} f(x) = \frac{4}{2}=2,
\lim_{x \to 2} f(x) = \frac{0}{4}=0,
\lim_{x \to 0}g(x)=\frac{-9}{-3}=3,
\text{and} \ \lim_{x \to 1} g(x) = \frac{-8}{-2}=4
.

Now let us consider what happens at x=-2 for f(x). Note that when you try to simply plug in x=-2 you get \displaystyle \frac{0}{0} which is undefined. For cases of \displaystyle \frac{0}{0}, first try to factor both the numerator and denominator. If both factor, cancel the common factor then try plugging in x = a again.
\lim_{x \to -2} \frac{4-x^2}{x+2}=\lim_{x\to-2} \frac{(2+x)(2-x)}{x+2}=\lim_{x\to-2} (2-x)=4
.
What happens at x=3 for g(x). Again when plug in x=3 you get \displaystyle \frac{0}{0} which is undefined.
\lim_{x \to 3} \frac{x^2-9}{x-3}=\lim_{x\to3} \frac{(x+3)(x-3)}{x-3}=\lim_{x\to3} (x+3)=6
.

subsection.title: Having a Limit at a Point
subsection.p:
We saw earlier that f has limit L as x approaches c provided that we can make the value of f(x) as close to L as we like by taking x sufficiently close
(but not equal to)
c.
If so, we write
\displaystyle \lim_{x \to c} f(x) = L.
We also saw that there are cases where a function can fail to have a limit. The graphs that follow are two such examples.

figure.caption: Functions f and g each fail to have a limit at c = 1.

subsection.p:
Essentially there are two behaviors that a function can exhibit near a point where it fails to have a limit.
In Figure above,
at the left we see a function f whose graph shows a jump at c = 1.
If we let x approach 1 from the left side,
the value of f approaches 2, but if we let x approach 1 from the right,
the value of f tends to 3.
Because the value of f does not approach a single number as x gets arbitrarily close to 1 from both sides,
we know that f does not have a limit at c = 1.

For such cases, we introduce the notion of
left and right
(or one-sided)
limits.

assemblage.title: One-Sided Limits
assemblage.p:
We say that f has limit L_1 as x approaches c from the left and write
\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) = L_1
provided that we can make the value of f(x) as close to L_1 as we like by taking x sufficiently close to c while always having x \lt c.
We call L_1 the left-hand limit of f as x approaches c.

Similarly, we say L_2 is the right-hand limit of f as x approaches c and write
\lim_{x \to c^+} f(x) = L_2
provided that we can make the value of f(x) as close to L_2 as we like by taking x sufficiently close to c while always having x \gt c.

subsection.p:
In the graph of y=f(x) in Figure,
we see that
\lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = 2 \ \ \text{and} \ \lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = 3
.
Precisely because the left and right limits are not equal,
the overall limit of f as x \to 1 fails to exist.

For the function g pictured at the right of Figure,
the function fails to have a limit at c = 1 for a different reason.
While the function does not have a jump in its graph at c = 1,
it is still not the case that g approaches a single value as x approaches 1.
In particular,
due to the infinitely oscillating behavior of g to the right of c = 1,
we say that the (right-hand) limit of g as x \to 1^+ does not exist,
and thus \displaystyle \lim_{x \to 1} g(x) does not exist.

assemblage.title: Two-Sided Limit
assemblage.p:
A function f has limit L as x \to c if and only if
\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) = L = \lim_{x \to c^+} f(x)
.

subsection.p: That is, a function has a limit at x = c if and only if both the left- and right-hand limits at x = c exist and have the same value.

The function f given below in Figure
fails to have a limit at only two values:
at x = -2
where the left- and right-hand limits are 2 and -1,
respectively
and at x = 2,
where \displaystyle \lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x) does not exist.
Notice: that even at values such as c = -1 and c = 3 where there are holes in the graph,
the limit still exists.

statement.p:
Let us consider \displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0}f(x). To do so we will consider the limit from either side and see if they are equal.
\lim_{x \to 0^-} f(x) = \lim_{x\to 0^-} 5x^2+1=1
\lim_{x \to 0^+} f(x) =\lim_{x \to 0^+} 3x+1=1
.

Since the two sides are equal then
\lim_{x \to 0} f(x) =1
.

Let us consider \displaystyle \lim_{x\to 2}g(x). To do so we will consider the limit from either side and see if they are equal.
\lim_{x \to 2^-} g(x) = \lim_{x\to 2^-} 5x-2=8,
\lim_{x \to 2^+} g(x) =\lim_{x \to 2^+} 4x-5=3
.

Since the two sides are not equal then
\lim_{x \to 2} g(x) =DNE
.

ul.li: To algebraically compute the limit \displaystyle \lim_{x \to c} f(x), first try plugging in x = c (if c is in the domain and f(x) is continuous). In the case that we have \frac{0}{0}, try factoring and cancelling common factors.

For a function f defined on an interval around a number c, \lim_{x \rightarrow c^-} f(x)=L_1 means that the value of f(x) gets as close as we want to a number L_1 whenever x is sufficiently close to c with x \lt c, assuming the value L_1 exists.

Similarly, for a function f defined on an interval around a number c, \lim_{x \rightarrow c^+} f(x)=L_2 means that the value of f(x) gets as close as we want to a number L_2 whenever x is sufficiently close to c with x \gt c, assuming the value L_2 exists.

The one-sided limits help to determine if a limit exists as x approaches a value c. More specifically, \displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow c} f(x)=L if and only if \displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow c^-} f(x)=L=\lim_{x \rightarrow c^+} f(x)
